top_comment.author: Collin Craven

comments.text:
+Amber Barton I'm glad to read about how much you like cats and appreciate 
them so much. I used to be a dog person, too. In fact, I just became a cat 
person!!  But I don't agree with some of the generalizations you make about 
dogs and the differences between cats and dogs and the reasons cats are 
"better" connected with their genetics. For example, it is hard wired into 
dogs to be domesticated, and that is hardwired into cats, as well. 
Otherwise, they would be just like small lions and tigers, which they are 
not!  The biggest difference in the behavior of cats and dogs in famillies 
is that wolves (ancestors of dogs) lived and hunted in packs, so they HAD 
to be more cooperative with each other. Felines are solitary hunters 
(except for lions in a pride.) You can tell they are used to living around 
other felines because they are so territorial with each other. I'd say cats 
tend to like each other, but only if they respect each other's territories. 
( I learned something from "My Cat From Hell" recently. He came into a home 
in which one cat was dominating the other cat like crazy and the victim cat 
was peeing all over the floor and hiding the rest of the time. Jackson 
didn't do anything with the aggressive cat. He did a serious of things with 
the victim cat to turn him into a "confident cat" and then, as a "confident 
cat," he stood up for himself with the aggressive cat, and territory got 
balanced, and the victim cat completely stopped peeing on the floor! I was 
really surprised that it was not a matter of re-training the aggressive 
cat. It was funny, too. The aggressive cat was this pale long-haired sweet 
looking ball of fluff. The victim cat was a large sleek black and white 
cat!!

 I think it would be interesting if someone did a study on the differences 
in personality between dog people and cat people, as you mentioned that you 
do see a difference.  I think cat people can recognize their cat's 
individuality and how it makes choices—and, after all, being so small, they 
are more sensitive and can't take as much roughousing (well, small dogs are 
more sensitive, too, aren't they?) and dog people when they see that, think 
that the cat doesn't care about the person and it is aloof.

I prefer it when people don't say that cats are better than dogs or dogs 
are better than cats. I think it totally depends on the preference of the 
owner. Also, another important thing that makes a difference is whether a 
dog or a cat was abused when young. Just like with people, it's very hard 
to get beyond that suspiciousness and lack of trust which they learned from 
being abused.

Here's something we could notice here online, on cat or dog discussions. 
Which people tend to post angrier posts, cat people or dog people.  Did you 
ever notice? I didn't—I just know there's a lot of unnecessary anger 
between people with different tastes.  And the reason I thought of that, is 
that I think these extremely angry people were abused as children. Maybe 
not physically abused, but a lot of disapproval and criticism.
comments.author: Wendalore65

comments.text:
Maybe that's true in the movies, but in reality, cats usually care very 
very much for their owners. The relationship between a gentle and caring 
owner and a sweet cat is a beautiful thing.  When you see images of people 
holding their cats, and the cat is very relaxed with its eyes half closed, 
that is a cat that is feeling love.  Of course, if an owner is cruel or 
rough with the cat, the cat will not love them.
comments.author: Wendalore65

comments.text:
My dog has an anti-social, non-loving, mean, "don't give a crap" 
personality whereas my cat snuggles with me, kisses me, follows me around, 
answers to her name, purrs and loves on me constantly, is the sweetest 
animal I've ever owned (and I've owned many dogs growing up) and I wouldn't 
trade her for the world.  And this is coming from someone who grew up and 
loved (and still does love) dogs their whole life until I got my first cat 
and that completely changed my opinion of cats.  I would rather have a cat 
over a dog ANY day.  Their independent but also loving because they CHOOSE 
to be not because it's hardwired in them to be dependent on humans. 
 They're fine defending themselves and will bring you gifts showing they 
care as well as respect you more than ANY dog I've ever had has respected 
me (aside from my border collie but she acted more like a cat if I'm being 
honest) and from my experience cat people and dog people are very different 
just as cats and dogs are.  Cats take time to grow to you, they need to 
learn to trust you, and develop a relationship over time and dogs are just 
immediately and blindly loyal and needy and have to be taught everything. 
 Cat people value that animal's individuality and independence and respect 
it as they do their owners and it transcends into life where they value 
relationships that take time and trust to develop instead of blindly 
trusting whoever they meet like dog people tend to do.  This is just from 
what I personally have seen and experienced in my life from being a dog 
person as a child and then a cat person at the current place in my life now 
and I see it a lot in people who are cat/dog people.  Dog people tend to 
like being depended on hence why they like dogs.  Dogs need that constant 
guidance and attention and someone who's going to lead them because they 
lack independence and they lack their own ability to realize right from 
wrong.  I just prefer how cats are more intelligent and have vast and 
complex personalities and take time to love you because that time you spend 
and let grow with the cat is so worth it in the end.  More loyal than any 
dog because they take the time to get to know you as well.
comments.author: Amber Barton

comments.text: Collin, you can leave and live in your ignorant bliss.
comments.author: joyjoyoo

You know, it's an horrible thing to say ''shoot your cat''. Shooting an

If people prefer cats, it's fine! Get a dog, and live on!

also, in the movies? Alright, we better all start living our lives by the

comments.author: DigikidForever

comments.text:
+Alex Shvartsman Jackson Galaxy does not recommend declawing cats.  He 
insists that  declawing cats is BAD. Also, there are many countries that 
outlaw declawing.  I think it is correct for anyone to "post stupid rants" 
online when it comes to declawing cats. (Although I have to say I don't' 
see any rants, stupid or otherwise. "Rants" have to be long to be called a 
"rant," don't they?) And this is Jackson Galaxy's thread here, so if he did 
need to be educated, this is where he could do it. When people post on the 
web, it can be very good way to educate people, in fact. My problem is what 
people go on and go, using horrible insulting language. Anything they are 
trying to teach gets obscured by their anger. 

If enough people educated other people online, maybe we could move towards 
making it illegal.  However, I've read a LOT of pro-declawing stuff online. 
It seems that people have been doing it for a long time, and people seem to 
think that their cat is fine. Other people say that maybe they don't know 
how much their cat could be in pain all the time, even now. Also, I've read 
that when the cat gets elderly, that's when problems from declawing get 
worse. so many people's can't aren't that old yet. I think it sounds like a 
topic that needs more exposure. I didn't know anything about it until a 
month ago when I started researching cats, see?
comments.author: Wendalore65

comments.text:
+doctypepublic
If you trim claws, neither of these will be the problem. Don't pretend that 
you are doing it for the cat - the cat doesn't mind being "caught up" and 
it most certainly doesn't appreciate having its toes chopped - you do 
realize these are amputations of last part of cat's toes, right? You cause 
A LOT of pain to your cat and maybe lifetime of chronic discomfort just 
because you are too lazy to trim the claws.
comments.author: jewelmarkess

comments.text:
I don't like being poked when my kitty kneads me.  The claws tend to also 
get caught in the carpet or the furniture, for example.  Kitty dislikes the 
process, but he tends to appreciate not getting hung up.
comments.author: doctypepublic

comments.text:
I don't bother either. I tried. With my previous cat, Mashka, I used to do 
it initially, but then I stopped and just used slipcovers on the sofa 
(until I got tired of the sofa, then I removed slip covers). She did go 
after the carpets, but they turned out pretty scratch-resistant. I now have 
two kittens, but they came scratching post trained. They saw the cardboard 
and sisal scratchers and the sisal kitty tree and went right for it. Mashka 
used to scratch me when she was young, but it was my fault in every case. 
She mellowed down with age and I learned to respect her space. The kittens 
are super-sweet, they don't scratch me even when I medicate them 
(ringworm). I tried to clip their nails initially when I first thought 
their lesions were from rough play, but they screamed like I was killing 
them and wiggled so it was really difficult.
comments.author: jewelmarkess

comments.author: NampaHiker

top_comment.text:
My girlfriend just told me that she put the cat on a vegan diet and is 
teaching him yoga for exercise since we live on the 4th floor of an 
apartment...﻿
top_comment.author: Kitty Sharts

comments.text:
Cats are—how do you say it?  Obligate Carnivores. They need to eat meat, an 
almost total meat diet. That vegan cat is going to slowly get sicker and 
sicker until she dies. If you Google this topic, you can find a lot of 
information about it and you can show your girlfriend. Of course, then it's 
up to her if she wants to ignore the truth and do it HER way.  But you can 
try to help poor kitty. My upstairs neighbors are vegetarians, because they 
are Sikhs (from India) but if they had a cat, they said, they would give it 
all meat. Cats do not have a choice, people do. Perhaps she should get a 
rodent of some kind. Guinea pigs, hamsters, mice. How about a rat? lol

Oh, and the kind of exercise a cat needs is not yoga. They already do that 
sort of yoga stretching anyway! For aerobic exercise, just get Da Bird or 
any kind of cat toys on strings etc and have a nice lively session of 
having the cat hunt down the prey!  Leap around the room!!  Then the cat 
will be full of joy and will get tired out and will be ready to settle down 
in her lap for nice cuddle!!  And remind her to not forget to add a 
scratching post—it is also a stretching post!!
comments.author: Wendalore65

comments.text: Well then you better put him on Prozac, cause that is one sad cat.
comments.author: Dog Will Hunt

top_comment.text:
We've always declawed the front paws only of our cats and it doesn't seem 
to have affected them negatively ever. In our old house are cat would roam 
the neighborhood/semi country and was the dominant cat in the whole area! 
with no front claws! She would get in fights and woop other cats with 
claws...flash forward to our new house in Suburbia and one of our cats 
still manages to catch birds, mice and everything he can find in our 
backyard!﻿
top_comment.author: STSairman

comments.text:
+Peggie cantellya I agree. I think that people who declaw cats should have 
their own fingers amputated up to the middle joint and see how they like 
it! That is essentially what you are doing when you declaw.
comments.author: MyBrainEatsEverything

comments.text:
Declawed cats can have peeing issues (litter box issues) and biting issues. 
They may be in constant pain for the rest of their lives after having their 
toes amputated. Most importantly, to me, and something I only recently 
learned, they will get early onset arthritis from being declawed. Cats walk 
on their toes, but after declawing, they need to rock back and walk 
"wrong", which causes arthritis when they are quite young. Knowing all of 
this, why would anyone think cats are okay with declawing? And why would 
you do it anyway? I have three declawed cats who are rescues that someone 
else declawed and I feel sorry for them every day.
comments.author: Peggie cantellya

comments.text:
Dont declaw them. U cant knownif they like it or not. Cats sometimes are 
pretty wierd . When they are in pain or dislike it. They wouldnt speak out 
like dogs does
comments.author: Orashi Ruki

comments.text:
You still should not declaw them. It's very very bad. Cats have high pain 
thresholds, so it's possible your cats have been in pain from it and you 
just don't realize it.
comments.author: MyBrainEatsEverything

top_comment.text:
Hi Jackson, would you please address the issue of suckling? It's becoming a 
real problem at home. I'd really appreciate it. Thanks! 

I have two kittens, Midas and Mojito. Both are 9 months and were adopted 
together in August in a shelter nearby. Midas was born in the shelter and 
stayed with his mother cat until he didn't want it anymore. My mother in 
law also adopted his sister. Mojito was found walking alone down the street 
with only a few days of life. The vet said it is a miracle he is alive. 
Both are extremely affectionate and happy, but Mojito is a bit shy and 
scared.

The only problem is, because Mojito didn't have his mother cat he never 
weaned. When I adopted them I was on vacation from college and spent most 
of my days at home. I think he sort of adopted me as his mom during this 
period. Now every time I give him affection just wants to suckle on me. It 
reached a point that I can't let him sleep with me anymore because he wakes 
me up several times during the night trying to suckle on my cheek, ears, 
nose, etc.

I've tried several methods to stop this habit. I've tried spraying with 
water, give a small tap on the nose, ignore him, put him on the floor, etc. 
Nothing works! I feel bad for him, I don't want to traumatize him or make 
him feel that I don't love him. But I wish I could pet him and sleep with 
him in bed without he only thinking about suckling on me all the time. Is 
there any solution to this problem? I also feel bad because Midas sleeps 
very well, but if Mojito can't sleep with me so can't Midas. I really need 
to find a solution to this problem ASAP! Any help or advise is welcome ﻿
top_comment.author: Liss Spinardi

comments.text:
Hi Dena, I already give him something soft to suckle on and he does it 
until he falls asleep. But he wakes up a couple of hours later and tries to 
suckle on my face. Then I give him something soft again and he goes back to 
sleep until he wakes up again and so on. It's like that the whole night, he 
keeps on waking me up to suckle on my face. It's very frustrating that I 
can't find a solution to this problem....
comments.author: Liss Spinardi

comments.text:
Is there a little soft toy or soft blanket or bit of cloth you could 
encourage him to use, maybe?  Rub some sort of  food on it that he likes to 
get him started. You could give him that at the same time that you cuddle 
him.  I have two brother kittens and one used to suckle on the other all 
the time.  I thought I was going to have to use the blanket method, but 
then the other kitten finally said "enough!" and would slap his brother for 
suckling on him. Also, there's a method horse people use to stop crib 
biting (horses chewing on wooden fences).  Put something on your skin like 
mild (very mild! lol) chilli paste or something.
comments.author: Dena McAbee

top_comment.text:
My cat scratched my furniture one time and I looked at him and held him paw 
and went "ohhhhhh nooooooooo!!!!" he knew it made me upset, so he stopped, 
but my cat loves me so, I don't know if that would work for everyone lol﻿
top_comment.author: mark smith

comments.text:
That's what worked for my cat when we first got him! Cats understand 
dialogue people! Let them know that scratching will result in a negative 
consequence like not getting the daily treat or something. It's that easy 
really (for most cases anyway) :)
comments.author: Kiwi Holmes

comments.text: That's awesome lol
comments.author: Michael Reed

comments.text:
Oh, wow!!!  I didn't know cats were like that!! ever!  I just fell in love 
with a cat that was staying at my house, and she is gone, to I'm getting 
ready to get my own cat!!! That will be interesting to see!!
comments.author: Wendalore65

comments.text:
Aw that's sweet :)
My cat's like that too, if she does something I don't like, I act sad and 
dismayed she won't do it again. A cat's main driving force seems to be 
politeness.
comments.author: spidaminida

top_comment.text:
What is declawing? We trim our cat's nails and she's a good girl. She gets 
a treat after trimming and she's happy.﻿
top_comment.author: Zdeni

comments.text:
Doesn't work with OUR kitty. She'll snap up her treats every time and then 
hiss up a storm the next time we clip her nails or brush her. The man who 
owns the house, I don't think he'd like to compromise by cutting her nails 
over 3 days. He's finicky about his furniture because he worked for 
everything he has. He wasn't born to it.
comments.author: Vicki Bee

comments.text:
I've read comments like "if we can cut of their balls, then why not their 
knuckles", so yeah... I'm an humanist, but reading shit like this is 
seriously weaking my faith in humanity.
comments.author: Anne Elk

comments.text:
+Anne Elk How stupid can somebody be to think that??? I'd cut of their 
knuckles to see how it's without them. And Jackson says in that video about 
declawing in detail that it's hurt them to go to the litter box, so they 
start peeing and pooping everywhere else. Just because of stupidity of 
people.
comments.author: Zdeni

comments.text:
+Zdeni
Well, I tried to teach her to scratch only her scratching post, but I 
woudn't say, that I've succeeded. She generally scratches only my old, ugly 
couch, so I'm actually quite OK with it. :) I thing that the most horrible 
thing about declawing is that many people think, that there is no 
difference to the cat whether the animal has it's knuckles or not.
comments.author: Anne Elk

comments.text:
+Anne Elk Hi Anne, I found some Jackson's video about it and I was 
disgusted.. It's so cruel I almost cried. If you teach your cat not to 
scratch on furniture, it's OK and there's just need to take care of its 
nails. That's just horrible.
comments.author: Zdeni

comments.text:
Declawing is amputating the 8 knuckles on the cat's front paws. Some 
shitheads do this, because their super expensive leather furniture is more 
important for them than the health and happy life of their cats.
comments.author: Anne Elk

top_comment.text:
I have a good reason to declaw you're cat if you have an apartment and the 
landlord says you have to so you cant have you're cat if you don't declaw 
you're cat﻿
top_comment.author: EPIC TACOZ

comments.text:
then you don't live there??? it's as simple as that. 
I'd rather leave my place, then abuse my pet and cripple them.
comments.author: TheMellojello21

comments.text:
+Louise Andrew
Starving and yet afford to have 3 cats?. Shame that a medical volunteer 
actually believe declawing is okay regardless of any okay declawed cats
comments.author: zozek

comments.text:
We had this situation with 3 cats we had owned for their whole lives.  We 
were starving students,  given an apt rent free for the summer while we 
volunteered medical services in an underserved area.  Unfortunately, the 
place had an IRRESISTABLE nubbly sofa.  We had no good alternative---give 
up our babies, render them harmless, or quit the volunteer job and go 
home.  We had all  of them (Siamese) declawed by a local vet.  They all 
recovered in about a day, and after the bandages were off never noticed 
that they didn't have claws.  Still exercised their digits on the sofa, but 
it did no harm.  One still could climb trees when she slipped outside on 
occasion.  But we kept them in, so no problem with predators.  And they 
loved each other, so no need to defend from themselves.  They all lived to 
be close to 20 years old, were affectionate, loyal, TALKATIVE and hassle 
free pets.  Oh yes, and they also all used the toiletl  Which was very 
helpful as we completed medical training and were absent for days while at 
the hospital.  Although I love Jackson, I think he is a bit "dog"matic at 
times.  So are many of his followers.  No one answer fits all.
comments.author: Louise Andrew

comments.text: That sentence does not make sense.
comments.author: Wendalore65

comments.text: No. Declaw is so cruel. It'd b nicer to give your cat away than to declaw it
comments.author: Saoirse Carruthers

top_comment.text:
How I stop my kitten from going on the table? xD 
She allowed anywhere in the house but she seems to prefer the table!!!﻿
top_comment.author: Kuro Yuy

comments.text: Did it work? :)
comments.author: Katrina Tapio

comments.text: Okay!! Going try that thank you :D
comments.author: Kuro Yuy

comments.text:
but if it's because she likes hanging around you and your laptop, then put 
the lid of a shoe box next to or behind the laptop (computers are warm and 
cats like that). A shoe box lid is like a kitty trap. she will sit in the 
box lid rather than on your computer or on you.
comments.author: Katrina Tapio

comments.text:
I have done... She still prefers the table were my laptop is x.x and clings 
to my sleeve or hand the whole time.... Yeah I am at the table lot sine I 
dont have a desk I use the table for my laptop ;(
comments.author: Kuro Yuy

comments.text:
just give her an other place close to it where she can go, like a shelf or 
cat furniture or something. obviously there is something very nice about 
the table, like do you hang around there a lot? is it in the middle of a 
room? any place where she can get a lot of attention is very alluring for a 
cat...
comments.author: Katrina Tapio

top_comment.text:
I had girlfriend who was messy and she wore her keys on her belt and it 
scratched my sofa. Guess what I didn't do? I didn't cut off her fingers!!!! 
so I won't declaw my cat. It's the top of her fingers. My cat Annie has 2 
places she scratches as her way of being nice to me. I didn't even have to 
ask her.﻿
top_comment.author: nicholas cremato

comments.text:
+Sven Hassel I have 3 rescued declaws and two of them have declaw issues. 
Also, vets do it thinking they're keeping cats in their homes, but if 25% 
of cats are declawed and 25% of cats in shelters are declawed, then this is 
clearly not working.
comments.author: Peggie cantellya

comments.text: +nicholas cremato Most declawed cats don't have complications
comments.author: Sven Hassel

comments.text:
I have never declawed a cat. But just a couple of months ago I found out it 
is harmful to them. I never knew.
comments.author: nicholas cremato

comments.text:
I am going to make this quote into a poster and use it at cat adoptions! 
This is priceless! Thank you so much for saying this in just this way!
comments.author: Peggie cantellya

top_comment.text:
Unfortunately, I'm a teenager and don't have much of a say. I told my 
parents how bad declawing was, and how I didn't want my new kitty cat to go 
through it, but they just went and did it when I was in school. The good 
thing is that it doesn't really seem to bother her, and she is an indoor 
cat. I just wish that she understood how bad her back claws hurt. She 
doesn't scratch, really. It's just when she lays on my lap or back or walks 
across me or jumps off/on me, she always seems to have her back claws 
out... There's no way she'd let me trim her claws, and my parents refuse to 
get caps for her claws, because they say that those are absolutely useless. 
*sigh* Any tips? If not, I'm sure I can probably deal with it. I dealt with 
my previous cat biting me whenever she got mad (like if I wasn't in bed at 
bedtime... She acted like a mother... Of course, I got her when I was 5, 
and she was a tortie.). Claws are actually a bit easier than that. :)﻿
top_comment.author: LoligothRosePrincess

comments.text:
Yes, she would be using her back claws a bit more to help steady and 
stabilize herself more.  I would keep a little blanket next to me when I 
sat down and as soon as I saw her coming, through the blanket over my lap 
as protection from the claws.  Of course, this would be hard to do in 
summer!  lol  It is possible that trimming her back claws would make her 
...hmmm, I don't really know the words.  insecure, unsteady, less 
confident...as it is her only form of traction.  Just a thought.  Good Luck!
comments.author: Dena McAbee

comments.text:
I'll try to give you a couple reasons as to why she might be using those 
back claws. But keep in mind, I can't get inside your cat's head. :)

1) When she jumps, she might be using those back claws for stabilization 
before take-off. Then, when take-off happens, your skin feels the results.
2) A reason why she might feel like she needs to stabilize herself may be 
because she lacks front claws. And so, she uses method #1. 
3) Some cats just don't realize that humans have pathetically thin skin and 
never learn to be careful with their claws. 
4) Her nails just may be so long that they poke you even if they're 
retracted.

I would say, start slowly getting her used to those back paws being 
touched. Touch her paw a little and give her a treat. Gradually start to 
touch and fiddle with her paws for longer amounts of time. Jackson's tips 
are spot on about trimming nails once you get there!
comments.author: Kimberly Wakefield

top_comment.text:
I have a question kind of related to claws. I got my cat, chubby, from a 
shelter about two months ago. She's roughly two years old, spayed, and 
still has her claws. Shes very affectionate and loves laying on my lap and 
being petted and played with, but she HATES being picked up. I pick her up 
and support her bum and keep her close but she freaks out and within 
seconds is scratching and trying to get away. Im afraid her previous owners 
do something to make her feel vulnerable when picked up. How can I make her 
comfortable and teach her that shes safe in my arms so that she can stop 
scratching and flailing about trying to escape?﻿
top_comment.author: Kaylarrrg

comments.text:
One of my cats is like this. She's loving but HATES being picked up. So 
when she stretches I try to pet her belly a little just to get her used to 
feeling that. I lift her correctly but I think she just is very afraid. 
When I do have to pick her up a make it very fast. I keep a blanket in the 
crate I use for transporting her to the vet so when she gets in there it 
smells like her. But I really try not to pick her up unless I absolutely 
have to. I try to honor that she just doesn't like it.
comments.author: Winnie Anderson

comments.text:
Many cats hate to be picked up. My mom's cat would come to us for affection 
only when he felt like it and would get really pissed if he was picked up. 
My cat on the other hand doesn't mind being picked up most of the time and 
will curl up in my arms without being prompted. If your cat doesn't like 
being picked up, I'd say that's OK and I wouldn't force it. There's nothing 
wrong with providing affection on their terms.
comments.author: Jessica Cejnar

comments.text:
One hand under the belly the other supporting the PAWS. Cats hate to have 
their feet dangling in the air.
comments.author: shcmoly

top_comment.text:
would masking tape work, because I am having a problem where my cat (jack 
Sparrow) Scratches at the foot Bottom base board! just one corner! and its 
my corner of the bed, I Tried the Glue on claws for jack,and they didn't 
pop off! Pets smart put them on an said they would pop off too, but it was 
to the point where jacks claws were Growing out of the fake claws and I had 
to cut the fake claws off, and he walked funny with them on and I didn't 
like that either, how well would masking tape work!? please help me 
Jackson, thanks bunches! :)﻿
top_comment.author: Tasha Ramsey

comments.text: No problem!
comments.author: Krystina C

comments.text: oh. ok Thanks hon :)
comments.author: Tasha Ramsey

comments.text:
Masking tape would not work because the tacky-yucky feeling that dispels 
cats from scratching isn't there. It needs to be double sided so there's 
stickiness on both sides.
comments.author: Krystina C

top_comment.text:
I have been a cat person my whole life and I don't have a cat to myself but 
there is one thing that keeps me from getting a kitten. My speakers. They 
have leather on the front and I'm afraid that the cat would scratch on it 
and I do NOT want to put the sticky stuff on the speakers. My speakers are 
Monitor Audio PL300, google it and you'll se the leather on the front.
Anyone PLEASE help? I hope you see this +Jackson Galaxy ﻿
top_comment.author: BoobieNizer

comments.text:
My cat scratches a cloth chair but has never scratched either of the 
leather couches. Different cats like different things. Definitely make the 
chicken wire fence, but it's a possibility you won't need it.
comments.author: bluowlie

comments.text:
We have expensive speakers! They do not have leather on them, though. I do 
feel like lather can be irresistible to cats. Ours don't mess with them so 
much because we have a tooon of cat towers and posts for them--but you 
could very well get a kitten who won't leave them alone. I recommend you 
get an older, less active cat. The older a cat gets the less destructive 
they get. Even get an older declawed cat! They get taken to the pound so 
much. They have other health issues like arthritis but maybe you can deal 
with them if the clawing is your main fear. If you are a cat person you 
should enjoy an older cat--they're less likely to be adopted and less 
destructive.
comments.author: tunasammich

comments.text:
I sort of feel like a dick for telling people what kind of speakers they 
are. I didn't mean to tell everyone how much they cost. Just wanted to give 
people an idea of how the leader is placed on the speakers, would be easier 
if you could post picture commens like on facebook. Lol now I'm just 
rambling... Thanks for the idea! 
No I could never put them away though :)
comments.author: BoobieNizer

comments.text:
Wow, those are some expensive speakers.  If you're handy and willing to 
invest some time, you can go to Home Depot or other hardware store, buy 
some chicken wire/fencing, some appropriate length poles to act as 
stabilizers, and build a 360 degree barrier around the entire thing.  Just 
make sure it is sturdy enough to hold a cat's weight because it will 
probably jump on to of it and might even decide to take a nap.  Also, make 
sure the wire is at least 6 inches away from the front of the speakers.  
Or, you can put your speakers in storage.
comments.author: Keith P

captions.text: All right.
Fine, Jackson, fine.

You told me all about
declawing and how terrible it.

Is And fine, fine, I
won't declaw my cat.

My cat is still
wrecking my house.

My cat is scratching
up my furniture.
My cat is scratching me.
I don't want my cat to scratch.
Now what do I do?

Well, calm down Sleepless
in Scratchville.
It's time to get catified.

If you watched episode
about declawing,

you know exactly where
I fall on the matter.

I mean, I made myself
pretty clear, right?
Don't do it.
Don't do it.

It's inhumane, it's cruel,
it's unusual, it's unnecessary.

And it rarely works in
solving behavioral problems.

It usually makes
other ones crop up.
And did I tell you it hurts?
You said, find.

And you said it in
loud, loud ways.

I mean, thank you
by the way, people.

The way you're coming out,
team Cat Mojo in force, right?

How do you live with
a cat and her claws?
Well, I'm going to tell you it.

There's a few things we
have to bear in mind.

Scratching is a
necessity for cats.
It's not a luxury.

Cats need to, first
of all, exercise
the top part of their body.

It's a nice way to grab
something and pull down and get
that exercise.

Also, it's a really important
part of marking territory.
Now remember, Cat Mojo 101.
Cats need to own places.

If they don't own places, they
become very, very insecure

and anxious, and they
act out in other ways.

If it is a necessary, if cats
do need to scratch, well then,

what are we going
to do about that?

The first thing that we
do is trim their nails.

You take either a nail trimmer
or a human nail clipper,

or the ones that they
sell in the stores that

are more like systems,
whatever suits your fancy.
You press the cat's pad.
And boink, out comes the nail.

All you've got to do
is take off the tip.

You don't have to
take off that part
where the red meets the white.

You don't have to worry
about hurting them that way.

You don't worry
about what we call

quicking them, which is
hitting that blood supply
and making everyone unhappy.
Just bump, and it's done.
It's also the approach, folks.

Just act as if you're just
walking up and you're say hi.

And things will get
much, much easier.
Also, catch them napping.

I mean, when your cat's
sleeping or just waking up,

you're having a lazy
moment together.

You can have clippers
by the side of your bed.

All you're doing is getting
the nail out and clipping.

If every time you
touch your cat's paws,
they're going to get clipped?

Then they're not going
to let you do it.

So associate it with positive
things, a nice quiet time.

And then maybe you
only get one nail
while you're sitting there.
That's fine.

Because over the course
of a couple days,
you'll get them all.

The next thing that we want
to start thinking about
is where they're scratching.

Remember, it's
territorially important.

There's two human scent
soakers-- your couch
and your bed.

Where do you spend the
most part of your time
when you get home from work?
Your couch and your bed.

And that's where
your scent is strong.
It's a scent soaker.

And because of that,
your cat is going

to want to compliment
your scent with theirs.

In the show, you've seen this,
I'm sure, a million times.
I get redundant.
The yes and the no.

Behind every no,
there has to be a yes.

If we don't want them scratching
on the arm of the chair,

we have to say, well, this
location is still important.

Let's say you use a
product like Sticky Paws.

Sticky Paws is
double-sided sticky tape

that is actually designed not
to actually stick to your couch.

But when your cat touches
it, it's kind of tacky
and they don't like it.

OK, we'll say no, and put sticky
paws down the arm of the couch.

But right next door, there
has to be a scratching post.

There has to be a scratching
post that works for them so

that they can compliment
your scent with them,

and leave a visual and scent
marker in a territorially
crucial area.

What makes a good
scratching post?

All right, let's
talk about that.

The first thing is
a nice wide base,

because if your cat goes to
scratch down and the thing

wobbles, well then,
the couch wins.

Does your cat prefer corrugated
cardboard or sisal rope
or carpeting or natural wood?
What is it your cat likes?

There are a lot
of nice scratches
out on the market there.

But you've got to sometimes look
in different places, you know?

You don't want to just go
for the first one you see,

and then get mad
when it doesn't work.

In a situation where
you have young children,

or if you're immune
compromised, things

like that-- which in the past
were kind of given reasons

to declaw a cat-- you can think
of something like Soft Paws.

And Soft Paws is a brand
name, but there are other ones
out there.

They're basically
just vinyl nail tips.
They go on.

They don't hurt,
nothing like that.

And the only downside is
that after a month or so,

they're just going to pop
off as the nail grows.

And then you trim the
nails and do it again.

It is a way that there's
no way that the nails can
do any damage.

I like that to be
sort of a last resort.
Because why do it?

Why go through all
the aggravation
if you don't have to?
Plus.

I like accommodating
the raw cat.

We want cats to be confident
in the areas that they scratch.

We want them to assert
themselves territorially.

We just want them to
do it in the place

that we want them to do
it, and not in the place
we don't want them to do it.

Don't forget, you can start
this when they're young.

I mean seriously, if you are
clipping your cat's claws

and giving them the yes and the
no, and they're a young kid,

you will not have a
problem as they grow up.

And there's a lot
of people out there

who are like, why would
I compromise for my cat?
You know, you've got children.
You've got spouses and partners.

And let me tell you
something, the compromise

involved with those guys
dwarfs the needs of your cat.

So listen, if you've got
to go out there and get

a scratching post, you've
got to put some sticky tape

on your couch, you've got
to go put Soft Paws on,

you've got to clip
your cat's nails.

That's the cost of having
a beautiful relationship
with your cat.

It is an invaluable
relationship,

and beautiful in
every single way.

Now you know everything
that you need

to know-- the basics,
anyway-- on making sure

that your furniture and
the people in your house

stay safe while keeping
your cat's claws intact.

Now, in the meantime folks, you
can find me anywhere, right?
Anywhere and everywhere.

Find me Twitter, Facebook,
InstaGram, Google+.
There's no excuse.
I am all over the place.

Be sure to join me on
Wednesday, February 5.
I'll answer your questions.

And we're going to talk
more about declawing.

So stay tuned for
more information.

But man, get that on your
calendar and do it now.

Hey, I've got to say
it one more time.

Folks, thank you so
much for the support

that you're showing that last
video that I put out there.

It's getting circulated
far and wide.
You are telling your friends.

We are finally going to
get that message out.
What's the message?
Declawing your cat is not OK.

Anyhow folks, until
we talk next time.

All light, all love,
all mojo to you.
Muah.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: How to Stop Your Cats From Scratching Furniture
